data.title: List of Nikon DX lenses for Nikon F mount in 2024
data.meta_description: Here is the list of all Nikon DX lenses for the F mount in 2024. All Nikon APS-C DSLR lenses are listed here!
data.text:
After having detailed the list of available lenses for the Canon EF-S mount, the equivalent mount for Canon cameras, I’ll present you today the one of Nikon DX lenses for the F mount of the brand. We’ll focus here on the lenses dedicated to the Nikon ASP-C DSLR cameras. The FX acronym reminds us that the lens was built for the brand’s full format DSLR cameras. As a reminder, there is a crop factor of 1.5 between the DX and FX sensor – the DX format being 1.5 times smaller than the FX format. To get the equivalent focal length on a full frame sensor, you will have to multiply the focal length by 1.5. For example, a 35mm focal length mounted on a DX camera will give an equivalent angle of view of a 50mm on an FX camera.

It is important to know that lenses intended for DX sensors are adapted to this type of sensor and thus offer a smaller size, weight and therefore a lower price. So, for those who bought a Nikon APS-C camera body, I strongly recommend sticking to the DX format when buying your lenses, even if the choice is much more limited than the lenses for FX sensors, I agree. Please note that you can of course use Nikon FX format lenses on your APS-C body. If you try doing the opposite (mounting a DX lens on an FX body), the camera will automatically crop the image to fit into the format. Otherwise, you will end up with a large vignetting on the edges of the image (the lens being not adapted to cover a Full frame sensor).

Tables below can be sorted according to the characteristic you want (focal length, max. aperture or filter diameter).

The page presented below is under construction. All the available lenses for the DX format are well mentioned in the tables below. I will progressively complete the page with personal opinions on the lenses and I hope I will be able to help you at best with your choice.

Nikon offers a wide range of lenses with standard focal lengths, ranging from the classic 18-55mm, 17-55mm and several interesting standard zoom lenses for people who want a unique lens, for example when traveling, such as the 18-140mm or 18-200m. Also, note that there are two fixed focal lengths, adapted to the DX format: a 35mm and a 40mm (which have 1:1 macro capabilities).

This type of lenses will be particularly adapted for daily life and portraits. By the way, here is our article detailing all the lenses we recommend from Nikon for portrait photography. You will find both standard and telephoto lenses, for both DX and FX mount (lenses that can be adapted on Nikon APS-C cameras).

Work was relatively easier here as the lenses are pretty much the same as those used for the Canon EF-S mount. In fact, third-party brands who wanted to enter the APS-C DSLR market generally offer the same lenses for Canon (EF-S) and for Nikon (DX). I found only 6 third-party brands, including 3 offering lenses with autofocus (Sigma, Tamron and Tokina). Note that, even if more and more people are switching to the mirrorless market, some third-party brands such as Tokina keep updating some old lenses, like the Tokina ATX-I 11-16mm F/2.8 CF or the Tokina ATX-I 11-20mm F/2.8 CF, two serious wide-angle lenses to consider.

In the past, Sigma has released a large number of lenses for the Nikon DX mount. I decided not to include Sigma’s “very old” lenses and only add the “newest” ones. Let’s remind that the acronym “DC” makes us know the lens is dedicated to an APS-C sensor. The OS symbol means that the lens is stabilized. Note that lenses with the “Art” label of the brand are the most recent ones, like the two standard lenses (18-200mm and 18-300m) and the three others with large aperture. Other lenses mentioned in the table are older but still to be considered anyway.

Tokina has a rather good reputation. I myself began with the old Tokina 11-16mm f/2.8 on my first Canon APS-C body. In the last few years, Tokina has decided to update several of these lenses, including the Tokina ATX-I 11-16mm f/2.8 CF. It is a very nice reference to seriously consider if you’re looking for a bright wide-angle lens offering a very nice image quality. Regarding the other lenses, I have left only the most recent ones, but you can find some more around the web.
